TITLE I--UNEMPLOYMENT COMPENSATION

SEC. 101. The title is the "Unemployment Compensation Extension Act of 2008".

SEC. 102. Increases first-tier benefits from 50 to 80 and extends the duration from 13 to 20 weeks.

SEC. 103. Introduces second-tier benefits. Section 4002 of the Supplemental Appropriations Act, 2008 is amended to include a special rule for individuals in extended benefit periods. Their account will be augmented by an amount based on their regular compensation or average weekly benefit amount. Extended benefit period criteria under the Federal-State Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 1970 include specific conditions for a state to be considered in such a period. The Federal-State Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 1970 sets criteria for extended benefit periods, including adjustments to section 203(f) for states, with limitations on individual account augmentation. SEC. 104 of the Supplemental Appropriations Act, 2008 amends provisions related to individual account augmentation under the Federal-State Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 1970. It specifies that no augmentation is allowed after March 31, 2009, and terminates compensation after August 27, 2009. SEC. 105 of the Act temporarily increases federal matching for the first week of extended benefits for states with no waiting week until December 8, 2009. SEC. 106 specifies the effective date. SEC. 106 specifies the effective date for amendments made by sections 102, 103, and 104 of the Supplemental Appropriations Act, 2008. Additional emergency unemployment compensation is payable only for weeks of unemployment after the enactment of the Act. TITLE IV--DIRECT BRIDGE LOAN PROVISIONS

SEC. 401. FINDINGS: Congress recognizes the urgent need for the automobile industry to secure credit and liquidity to prevent adverse effects on the economy.

SEC. 402. PURPOSES: The purpose of this provision is to address the challenges faced by the automobile industry in obtaining essential credit and liquidity. The purpose of this title is to provide immediate authority and facilities to the Secretary to restore liquidity and stability to the US automobile industry, stimulate manufacturing and sales of US-made vehicles, enhance the production of energy-efficient vehicles, and preserve jobs in the industry. The curr_chunk discusses the importance of safeguarding the domestic automobile industry, ensuring benefits for retirees and their dependents, and providing the Secretary with authority to restore stability to financial institutions. The curr_chunk discusses the Emergency Direct Loan Program under SEC. 403. The Secretary will provide loans totaling $25 billion to automobile manufacturers and component suppliers who meet specific criteria to prevent adverse effects on the US economy. Loan allocation will prioritize those with operations critical to the overall economy. The Secretary will prioritize loan distribution based on the impact of manufacturing operations on the US economy, employment levels, and automobile industry segments. Applicants must submit a detailed plan on how the funds will ensure long-term financial viability and stimulate US automobile production. SEC. 404 states that the Federal Government will cover costs of loans under this title from funds available to the Secretary, excluding specific funds described in section 115(a). SEC. 405 addresses the timing of disbursements. SEC. 405 outlines the timing of disbursements for loans under this title, with specific deadlines for application acceptance, eligibility determination, and disbursement of loan proceeds to eligible applicants. The term to maturity of loans under this title is 10 years, with a possible extension determined by the Secretary. The interest rate is 5 percent for the first 5 years and 9 percent thereafter. Loans require warrants or debt instruments from the borrower and can be prepaid without penalty. The Secretary requires recipients of loans under this title to meet standards for executive compensation and corporate governance, including limits on compensation to prevent excessive risks. Recovery of bonus or incentive compensation paid to senior executive officers is also mandated. The Secretary mandates limits on executive compensation and corporate governance for loan recipients under this title, including prohibiting golden parachute payments, bonus or incentive compensation over $250,000, and compensation plans that could manipulate reported earnings. The text defines "senior executive officer" as a top 5 highly paid executive of a public company and "golden parachute payment" as any payment to such an officer upon departure. The text prohibits common stock dividends from being paid by any recipient of a loan under this title for the duration of the loan. Title IV of the Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008 includes oversight provisions for loans made under this title, applying certain sections in a similar manner as transactions under title I. Technical and conforming amendments are made to the table of contents. Title IV of the Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008 outlines direct bridge loan provisions, including findings, purposes, an emergency direct loan program, funding sources, disbursement timing, terms and conditions, and oversight. Additionally, references are added to the Act for clarity. Title IV of the Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008 includes direct bridge loan provisions and references for clarity. Section 301 designates all provisions as emergency requirements to meet fiscal year 2008 needs.
